unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Law of Large Numbers
question_text: From a large population, you take a random sample of size $n = 30$ and obtain a sample mean $\bar{x} = 21.34$ and $s = 3.2$ . You add additional members of the population to this sample. What does the “law of large numbers” tell us about the mean and standard deviation of this ever-increasing sample?

choices.text: As n n increases, the expected values of the sample mean and sample standard deviation will approach the population mean and population standard deviation.
As n n increases, the expected value of the sample mean will approach the population mean.
As n n increases, the expected value of s s will be σ σ .
As n n increases, the distribution will become more and more skewed.
As n n increases, the values of the sample mean ¯ x x ¯ and s s will vary significantly.
